parse.title: List of host cities of the ABU Song Festivals

text.*:
This page is a list of cities and venues that have hosted the ABU Radio Song Festival, ABU TV Song Festival, and ABU International Dance Festival, one or more times. Future venues are shown in italics. The first venue in both the ABU Radio Song Festival 2012 and ABU TV Song Festival 2012, coincided with the 49th General Assembly of the Asia-Pacific Broadcasting Union. The host cities of the ABU Radio Song Festivals from 2014 onwards are elected during ABU Administrative Council meetings. Whereas the host cities of the ABU TV Song Festivals remain to coincide to take place in the host country of the ABU General Assembly meetings.[1]

Contents

  • 1 ABU Radio Song Festival
  • 2 ABU TV Song Festival
  • 3 ABU International Dance Festival
  • 4 See also
  • 5 References

ABU Radio Song Festival[edit]

Contests Country City Venue Years Date
1  South Korea[2] Seoul KBS Hall 2012 11 October 2012
 Sri Lanka[3] Colombo Stein Studios 2014 23 May 2014
 Myanmar[4] Yangon National Theatre of Yangon 2015 29 May 2015
 China[5] Beijing China National Radio Auditorium 2016 26 April 2016
 Thailand[6] Bangkok TBA 2017 27 April 2017
 Kazakhstan[7] Astana Kazmedia Centre 2018 11 July 2018

ABU TV Song Festival[edit]

Contests Country City Venue Years Date
1  South Korea[8] Seoul KBS Hall 2012 14 October 2012
 Vietnam[9] Hanoi Hanoi Opera House 2013 26 October 2013
 Macau[10] Macau Sands Theatre 2014 25 October 2014
 Turkey[11] Istanbul Istanbul Congress Center 2015 28 October 2015
 Indonesia[12] Bali Bali Nusa Dua Convention Centre 2016 22 October 2016
 China[13] Chengdu S1 SRT Studio 2017 1 November 2017

ABU International Dance Festival[edit]

Contests Country City Venue Years Date
1  India[14] Hyderabad Shilpakala Vedika 2017 15 January 2017

See also[edit]

  • List of host cities of the Eurovision Song Contest
  • List of host cities of the Junior Eurovision Song Contest

References[edit]

  1. ^ "ABU gets leaders' backing for increased activities". ABU. Retrieved 23 May 2013. 
  2. ^ "ABU Radio Song Festival 2012". Asia-Pacific Broadcasting Union. Retrieved 16 August 2012. 
  3. ^ "ABU gets leaders' backing for increased activities". ABU. Retrieved 23 May 2013. 
  4. ^ "ABU Radio Song Festival 2015". ABU. Archived from the original on 4 December 2014. Retrieved 9 November 2014. 
  5. ^ Granger, Anthony (30 June 2015). "China to host ABU Radio Song Festival 2016". eurovoix.com. Eurovoix. Retrieved 30 June 2015. 
  6. ^ Halliwell, Jamie (30 July 2016). "ABU Radio Song Festival to be held in Thailand in 2017". eurovoix-world.com. Eurovoix. Retrieved 1 August 2016. 
  7. ^ "Kazakhstan To Host ABU Radio Song Festival 2018". eurovoix-world.com. Eurovoix World. 31 October 2017. Retrieved 6 June 2018. 
  8. ^ "ABU Song Festival 2012". Korean Broadcasting System. Archived from the original on 18 February 2013. Retrieved 16 August 2012. 
  9. ^ "ABU 50th General Assembly and Associated Meetings". ABU. Retrieved 11 April 2013. 
  10. ^ "3rd ABU TV Song Festival scheduled to take place in Macao 2014". escKaz.com. Retrieved 15 September 2013. 
  11. ^ Granger, Anthony (20 October 2014). "ABU TV Song Festival 2015: Turkey To Host". eurovoix.com. Eurovoix. Retrieved 22 October 2014. 
  12. ^ Granger, Anthony (6 January 2016). "ATSF16 5th ABU TV Song Festival to be held in October 2016". eurovoix-world.com. Eurovoix. Retrieved 7 March 2016. 
  13. ^ Granger, Anthony (18 April 2017). "ABU TV Song Festival 2017 participation deadline window closes". eurovoix-world.com. Eurovoix. Retrieved 25 April 2017. 
  14. ^ Granger, Anthony (8 June 2016). "India launches ABU International Dance Festival selection". eurovoix-world.com. Eurovoix. Retrieved 8 June 2016.
